description: From Latin colōnia (“colony”), from colōnus (“farmer; colonist”), from colō (“till, cultivate, worship”), from earlier *quelō, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷel- (“to move; to turn (around)”).

entries.meaning: An area under the political control of another country and typically occupied by settlers (colonists) from it, or by their descendants.
examples: Much of the eastern United States was formerly a British colony; other areas were French, Spanish, Dutch, or Swedish colonies.
Bermuda is a crown colony of Great Britain.

entries.meaning: A group of people who settle such an area and maintain ties to their native country, and (later) their descendants.
A group of people, of one nationality, ethnic group, or language, residing in a different country, city, or area; the area such people occupy.
examples: a colony of British expats in Spain
The Amana Colonies in Iowa were settled by people from Germany.

entries.meaning: A group of people with similar interests, occupations, or characteristics, living in a particular area; the area such people occupy.
examples: a nudist colony;   the statue was put up right in the middle of the artist colony
a leper colony on the outskirts of town; most buildings in the penal colony were made of concrete

entries.meaning: (biology) A group of organisms of same or different species living together in close association.
examples: a colony of specialized polyps and medusoids

entries.meaning: A group of bacteria, fungi or other cells cultured together, especially from a single cell.

examples: Our colony is quite small, but each apartment is large.

entries.meaning: A local group of Beaver Scouts.
A potential new chapter of a fraternity or sorority awaiting official recognition from their headquarters.
